equipment.notes: Most common free weight. Fixed bilateral loading. Trap bar and safety squat bar shift loading mechanics significantly.
Allows unilateral work and greater ROM. Higher stabilization demand than barbell. Ideal for addressing bilateral deficits.
Offset center of mass creates unique loading. Excellent for ballistic movements (swings, cleans, snatches) and goblet variations.
Used for plate-loaded exercises (front raises, pinch carries) and as added resistance. Limited load progression.
Constant tension throughout ROM. Adjustable angle allows targeting muscles at different lengths. Single attachment point.
Two independent cable stacks. Allows unilateral work with cable benefits. Greater stabilization than single cable due to independent loading.
Fixed movement path with pin-loaded weight stack. Cam design creates variable resistance curve. Specific machine captured in exercise name.
Fixed path like selectorized but loaded with plates. Often allows heavier loads. Brands like Hammer Strength common in gyms.
Barbell on fixed vertical or angled track. Reduces stabilization demand. Angled variant (5-7Â°) allows more natural bar path for pressing.
No external load. Progression via leverage changes, ROM, tempo, or adding external load. High relative strength component.
Reduces effective bodyweight via bands or counterweight. Assistance typically greatest at bottom (stretched) position.
Bodyweight movements with added external load. Allows progressive overload beyond bodyweight. Common for dips, pull-ups, push-ups.
Resistance increases as band stretches (ascending curve). Opposite of gravity - hardest at shortened position. Good for accommodating resistance.
Straps anchored overhead. Body angle determines resistance. Extremely high stabilization demand due to unstable handles. TRX is common brand.
Barbell anchored at one end creating arc movement. Unique pressing angles (easier on shoulders). Good for rotational work.
Spherical weighted ball. Excellent for explosive throws, rotational movements, and core work. Slam balls designed for impact.
Selectorized machines with independent arms (e.g., converging chest press). Allows unilateral training with machine stability benefits.
Standard dip station. Width affects chest vs triceps emphasis. Found in most gyms.
Suspended rings requiring maximum stabilization. Significantly increases muscle activation due to instability. More common in CrossFit gyms.
Hexagonal bar allowing neutral grip and centered load. Reduces spinal stress vs conventional deadlift. High handles reduce ROM.
Cambered bar with angled grips. Reduces wrist strain during curls and skull crushers. Typically 15-25 lbs.
Inflatable exercise ball. Adds instability challenge to exercises. Common sizes: 55cm, 65cm, 75cm based on height.

free_weight.description: Traditional weights subject only to gravity. Highest skill/stabilization requirements.

cable.description: Pulley-based systems providing constant tension throughout ROM.

machine.description: Fixed movement path equipment. Lowest stabilization demand, highest isolation potential.

bodyweight.description: Using body mass as resistance. Includes assisted and weighted variations.

band.description: Elastic resistance with ascending resistance curve.

specialty.description: Specialized tools for specific training applications.

resistanceCurveDescriptions.gravity: Resistance determined by gravity vector. Hardest at position where moment arm is longest (often stretched position). Easier as joint approaches lockout.
resistanceCurveDescriptions.constant: Even resistance throughout entire ROM. Characteristic of cable/pulley systems.
resistanceCurveDescriptions.variable: Resistance changes based on cam/lever design. Well-designed machines match strength curve of target muscle.
resistanceCurveDescriptions.ascending: Resistance increases through ROM. Characteristic of bands - hardest at shortened/contracted position.
